description.p: Long before the records of men, in the soaring Storm Giant Citadels that drift above the highest peaks, the High Runesmiths struck a deal with the sky itself. They did not use steel or iron, but harvested a condensed cyclone from the heart of a primordial hurricane, binding it into the shape of a blade with runes of pure willpower. Tempest Calamity is the physical manifestation of that ancient pact—a weapon that thunders with the weight of a thousand storms and smells of ozone and impending judgment. It is a sword destined for the 'Herald of the High Heavens,' and its history is irrevocably bound to the Prophecy of the Eternal Dawn. According to the seers, as light rains upon the City of the Dead and the 'Two Thirteen' years draw to a close, this blade will be the only force capable of meeting the Storm Dragon’s ascent. When drawn, the clouds above boil in ancestral recognition, for the blade does not merely serve its master—it prepares the world for the clash of titans foretold in the stars. To wield it is to hold the eye of the hurricane in your palm, becoming the lightning that strikes before the final thunder of the dragon’s return.
You have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Additionally, it deals an extra 1d6 lightning damage and 1d6 thunder damage on a hit.

Master of Winds. While attuned to this weapon, you are immune to the Deafened condition and have Resistance to Lightning and Thunder damage. You have a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can hover while flying.
Giant Craftsmanship. While attuned to this weapon, you can speak, read, and write Giant. Furthermore, you become proficient with Smith's Tools.

Chain Lightning Strike (3/Long Rest). When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can cause a bolt of lightning to arc from the target to up to three other creatures of your choice within 30 feet of it. Each secondary target must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw, taking 6d8 lightning damage on a failure, or half as much on a success. You can use this feature thrice per long rest.

Static Discharge (1/Short Rest). As a bonus action, you overcharge your body with electrical energy for 1 minute. Any creature that hits you within 120 feet of you during this time takes 2d8 lightning, thunder or force damage of your choice, and it must make a DC 18 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, creature cannot take reactions until the start of its next turn.

Eye of the Tempest (1/Long Rest). You can use an action to release the storm within the blade. For 1 minute, a 30-foot-radius aura of heavy rain and howling winds surrounds you. All ranged weapon attacks entering or leaving the aura have Disadvantage, the area becomes Difficult Terrain for hostile creatures and at the start of each of your turns, any hostile creature in the aura takes 2d10 thunder damage. You can use this feature once per long rest.

description.p: “Luckily, this time, the samurai were prepared. While the lesser samurai cut through the demonic underlings, radiant arcs of energy blossoming out from their onikiri to strike down the hordes of stinking dretches, their sensei locked eyes with the huge, bulbous demon. A circle cleared as both samurai and demonlings subconsciously made space for the impending duel. If the sensei could hold the demon’s attention for long enough, the day would be theirs.” — Saga of the Battle for Black Rock
This weapon has 6 charges and regains 1d6 expended charges daily at dawn. While holding it, you can cast the light cantrip on the blade at will.

Divine Wrath. As a bonus action while holding the sword, you can expend 1 charge to imbue it with crackling radiant energy until the end of your next turn. While imbued, this sword deals an extra 1d6 radiant or lightning damage of your choice to each target it hits. In addition, the first time you hit with an attack using the imbued sword on each of your turns, each Fiend within 10 feet of the target must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 radiant or lightning damage of your choice as crackling energy arcs out towards it.

Demon Lure. As a bonus action while holding the sword, you can expend 2 charges to draw the attention of one creature you can see within 30 feet of you, forcing it to make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. Fiends make this saving throw with disadvantage. On a failure, the creature becomes fixated on you for 1 minute. While fixated, the creature is incapacitated and its speed is reduced to 0 feet. This effect ends if you attack any other creature, if you cast a spell, if you’re more than 30 feet away from the fixated creature at any point, or if it takes any damage from you or a creature friendly to you.

div.p: To hold Judgment’s Ember is to carry a shard of a dying star that has been taught the meaning of justice. Forged by the elite smiths of the Jaeger Corps, these blades were never intended to be singular relics, but a burning standard carried by those brave enough to look the Scourge in its many eyes. Among all who bore the flame, none were more legendary than Gideon Harrow, a bastion of the Jaeger whose sword was the first light seen in the darkest pits of the rot. Yet, the tragedy of the Scourge Hunt spares no one; Gideon fell not to the tooth or claw of the beast, but to the slow, insidious corruption that turned his righteous fire into an aberrant, everflaming nightmare. As a Fallen Hunter, Gideon became a scorched ghost of his former self—an eldritch horror of eternal ash that turned this holy implement against his own kin, hunting the hunters with a twisted, sacrificial zeal. For years, the ember burned with a corrupted, fratricidal heat until the path of the Fallen Hunter crossed with five destined souls: Orv Bezmedan, Zephyr, Luwanna, Stephen, and Rin. In a battle that shook the foundations of the Burning North Forest, the heroes did what the Jaeger could not—they quenched the blade’s madness in Gideon’s own tortured blood, granting the old warrior a final, cooling peace and reclaiming the ember to once again serve as the ultimate, searing answer to the darkness.

description.p: You have a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Additionally, it deals an extra 2d6 fire damage on a hit.
Searing Bane. This weapon deals an additional 1d10 fire or radiant damage to Aberrations and Fiends.

Jaeger’s Intuition. While attuned to this blade, you have Advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks to track Aberrations and Intelligence (Nature) checks to identify their weaknesses. You can also sense the presence of Aberrations within 1 mile, though you do not know their exact location.

Mantle of the Purifying Flame. The intense heat of the blade protects its wielder. While attuned to this sword, you have Resistance to Fire and Radiant damage. Additionally, you are Immune to the effects of extreme heat and are not affected by high-temperature environments.

Scourge-Fire Mastery. The fire produced by this blade is forged from pure righteous will, making it nearly impossible to resist. While attuned to this weapon, your attacks, spells and features ignores Fire Resistance. Furthermore, you treat Fire Immunity as Fire Resistance when dealing damage with this sword. Creatures that Immune to fire damage are treated as having resistance instead.

Ashen Leap (1/Long Rest). As an action, you transform into a swirling pillar of ash and flame, soaring into the air and crashing down at a point you can see within 60 feet. Upon impact, each creature of your choice within 20 feet of that point must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 6d8 fire damage and is knocked Prone. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked prone. You can use this feature once per long rest.

The Burning Decree (Proficiency Bonus/Long Rest). As a bonus action, you can stoke the blade's flames to judge your foes. Until the start of your next turn, the weapon deals an extra 1d8 fire or radiant damage of your choice. Any creature hit by an attack while this feature is active has its speed reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus per Long Rest.
